content: Got it, thanks for your help.
You're welcome! How are you feeling today? Anything on your mind you'd like to talk about?
I’m feeling okay, I guess. Mostly just tired and stressed. I came here because I’ve been having a hard time sleeping—my thoughts won’t stop racing at night.

That sounds really tough, having racing thoughts at night when you're trying to rest. Sleep is so important, and it can be exhausting when you're not getting enough. What kinds of thoughts tend to keep you up?

It's mainly work stuff. I'm worried about getting fired. Things at my job have been tense lately, and with all the talk of layoffs and the economy being unstable, I feel like I'm at the top of the list to go. I just keep running through all the "what if" scenarios in my head, and it spirals from there.

It sounds like there's a lot of uncertainty at work, and that's weighing heavily on your mind at night. It's completely understandable to feel overwhelmed when facing something as big as job security—it’s a lot to carry. How have you been managing all of these racing thoughts when they come up?

Honestly, I haven't really been managing them at all. I just lie there, thinking about everything that could happen, and I can't seem to stop. Sometimes I'll stare at my phone to distract myself, but that doesn't really help either. It's like I can’t turn my brain off.

It’s hard when your mind feels like it’s constantly spinning, and even the things you try, like scrolling on your phone, don’t stop the cycle. That must be exhausting. What’s it been like for you to handle work during the day when you’re not sleeping well at night?

It’s been rough. I feel like I’m dragging myself through the day, constantly tired and on edge. My patience is thinner, and I’m worried that my exhaustion might hurt my work performance, which just makes me stress even more. It feels like a never-ending loop.

That sounds so challenging—being exhausted while also trying to keep it together at work, all the while worrying about job performance. It seems like the stress and lack of sleep are feeding off each other, making it harder to get a break. What do you think might help to start breaking that cycle?
